awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Designing and Enacting Mathematically Captivating Learning Experiences for High School Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
This design and development project explores how secondary mathematics teachers can plan and enact learning experiences that spur student curiosity, captivate students with complex mathematical content, and compel students to engage and persevere (referred to as "mathematically captivating learning experiences" or "MCLEs"). This study is important because of persistent disinterest by secondary students in mathematics in the United States. This study will examine how high school teachers can design lessons so that mathematical content itself is the source of student intrigue, pursuit, and passion. To do this, the content within mathematical lessons (both planned and enacted) is framed as mathematical stories and the felt tension between how information is revealed and withheld from students as the mathematical story unfolds is framed as its mathematical plot. The Mathematical Story Framework (Dietiker, 2013, 2015) foregrounds both the coherence (does the story make sense?) and aesthetic (does it stimulate anticipation for what is to come, and if so, how?) dimensions of mathematics lessons. The project will generate principles for lesson design usable by teachers in other settings and exemplar lessons that can be shared. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Specifically, this project draws from prior curriculum research and design to (a) develop a theory of teacher MCLE design and enactment with the Mathematical Story Framework, (b) increase the understanding(s) of the aesthetic nature of mathematics curriculum by both researchers and teachers, and (c) generate detailed MCLE exemplars that demonstrate curricular coherence, cognitive demand, and aesthetic dimensions of mathematical lessons. The project is grounded in a design-based research framework for education research. A team of experienced high school teachers will design and test MCLEs (four per teacher) with researchers through three year-long cycles. Prior to the first cycle, data will be collected (interview, observations) to record initial teacher curricular strategies regarding student dispositions toward mathematics. Then, a professional development experience will introduce the Mathematical Story Framework, along with other curricular frameworks to support the planning and enacting of lessons (i.e., cognitive demand and coherence). During the design cycles, videotaped observations and student aesthetic measures (surveys and interviews) for both MCLEs and a non-MCLEs (randomly selected to be the lesson before or after the MCLE) will be collected to enable comparison. Also, student dispositional measures, collected at the beginning and end of each cycle, will be used to learn whether and how student attitudes in mathematics change over time. Of the MCLEs designed and tested, a sample will be selected (based on aesthetic and mathematical differences) and developed into models, complete with the rationale for and description of aesthetic dimensions.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Dietiker completed the CAREER: Designing and Enacting Mathematically Captivating Learning Experiences for High School Mathematics Project (ID # 1652513). In this project, Dr. Dietiker’s research team collaborated with six experienced teachers across five years to explore how high school mathematics lessons could be designed to increase student interest and engagement, such as inspiring curiosity, sparking surprise, and building suspense. Although other studies have documented how the use of interesting contexts, digital games, or other novel elements can improve student experiences in mathematics, this study focused on how lessons addressing advanced core mathematical topics, such as the study of the roots of polynomials or geometric proof, could be designed so that students describe the mathematical content with descriptors such as “intriguing” or “fascinating.” 

To design the mathematics lessons, the teachers used a new design approach, namely, to think about the unfolding ideas as a lesson as a story. That is, the teachers approached the task of lesson design by thinking about the emotional experiences they wanted their students to experience, such as delight or awe, and then they mapped out a sequence of activities that could get that mathematical story to be experienced. For example, one teacher designed a lesson on linear functions as a story, and to do so, she created a storyboard (see the attached storyboard).

This way of interpreting the lesson enabled teachers to approach lesson design with new tools. For example, they now could recognize how providing too much information early in a lesson removed an exciting opportunity for surprise later in the lesson. Furthermore, this approach enabled teachers to design lessons that would incrementally increase a sense of mystery, allowing these lessons to build student suspense to a point where students might ask about the mathematical relationship. Each teacher designed 3 lessons with this approach, which were referred to as “mathematically captivating learning experiences,” or MCLEs. MCLEs were designed to enable a sense of urgency and captivation to build across a lesson, motivating students to persist through some frustration and mathematical challenges that are normally encountered by students in secondary mathematics classrooms that center instruction on problem solving and student reasoning.

Through multiple cycles of designing and testing  MCLE lessons in class with students, the teachers and researchers were able to connect how certain narrative structures in their mathematics lessons enabled these new types of experiences, such as surprise. Then, by comparing how each class of students described their experiences in the MCLE lessons with randomly-selected lessons from the same course, the research team studied whether student experiences with MCLEs were the same or different from what they experienced in their regular lessons. Overall, students rated the MCLE lessons as more interesting, and this finding was statistically significant. Moreover, students reported more positive, varied aesthetic experiences (e.g., suspense, surprise) in MCLEs than in other lessons with the same teacher and students. These findings provide evidence that designing lessons as mathematical stories shows promise and can offer students more positive aesthetic experiences in mathematics.

Furthermore, we were able to learn about the qualities of mathematics lessons that are very interesting to students. By comparing those lessons that had the most evident student interest (based on surveys), we identified eight characteristics that distinguish captivating lessons and show how some, such as the average number of questions under consideration at any point in the lesson, are strongly related to student aesthetic experiences. In addition, the lessons that students described as more interesting included more instances of misdirection, such as when students’ false assumptions provide opportunities for surprising results. These findings point to the characteristics of future lesson designs that could enable more students to experience curiosity and wonder in secondary mathematics classrooms.
